section:
== DocBook Tags
So far you have used a very limited set of DocBook attributes. The following chapter presents more tags which you typically need in a DocBook document.
=== Markup
.Table Title |===
=== Important Docbook tags
|Tag |Explanation
|
| Allows you to enter special signs into the text which would be otherwise interpreted by DocBook.
| <programlisting> </programlisting>
| Highlights the text as coding. You can also specify the programming language of this listing, e.g., language="java" or language="xml". This information can, for example, be used for syntax highlighting.
| <wordasword></wordasword>
|Indicates a special word
| <parameter class='command'>/w`
| Describes a parameter; `class` can be command, function, option
| <guilabel> </guilabel>
|Label on a GUI
| <guibutton> </guibutton>
| Button on a GUI
| <filename class="directory">/usr/bin`, `db2html`
|Directory or filename
| <emphasis> </emphasis>
|Highlights the text
| <xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="example1.txt" />
| Includes `example1.xml` as text, so the file can contain tags, etc.
| http://www.heise.de/newsticker">German IT News</ulink>.
|Paste a hypertext link into the document.
| &
| Creates the ampersand (&) sign. Can, for example, be used in links.
|===
=== Warnings
To define warning messages, DocBook provides several tags. The following list gives an overview of them.
tip
note
important
warning
caution
The following snippet shows how to use these.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/warning/warning.xml[] ----
=== Line break
You can create an explicit line break with the <sbr/> command.
=== References to other elements
You link to different elements in Docbook with <xref linkend="id_of_the_element"/> .
=== Legal Notice
You can define legal notices where you state the conditions for reproduction like traditional copyright or an open content license. These tags are confined to meta-information.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/legalnotice.xml[] ----
=== Index
You create an index in your document with the <index/> entry.
To create index elements, you can use the following:
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/indexelement1.xml[] ----
You can add a secondary index term.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/indexelement2.xml[] ----
You can also place a reference to another index term.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/indexelement3.xml[] ----
=== Tables You can create a table via the following coding.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/exampletable.xml[] ----
=== Lists You can create non-numbered lists like this:
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/simplelist.xml[] ----
You can create numbered lists like this:
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/numberedlist.xml[] ----
=== Links You can create links like this
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/link/examplelink.xml[] ----
=== Graphics
DocBook has no restrictions what kind of graphic format you use, e.g. JPEG, PNG or SVG. You can include graphics via the following tag. The optional `"phrase"` is used in HTML output to define the mandatory `"alt"` attribute of image.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/images/images.xml[] ----
You can also specify different graphics for different output formats.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/images/images2.xml[] ---- You can also embed a figure with enumeration and header.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/images/figure.xml[] ----
=== Menus
To define menu paths, as, for example, menu:File[New Project], use the following
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/gui/menu.xml[] ----
=== Keyboard Shortcuts
To define keyboard as, for example,
Ctrl Space
, use the following
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="./examples/gui/shortcut.xml[] ----
